intro: Mormodes tezontle, commonly known as Mexican nightshade, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like tomatoes and potatoes. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in the evening, giving it its common name. Its leaves are typically oval-shaped and have a slightly hairy texture. The fruit is a small, orange-red berry that ripens in late summer and is often used in traditional medicine.
